reference.author: Stuart J. Kolner
reference.unstructured: For an extensive review of Crosstalk XVI, see Stuart J. Kolner, “The IBM PC as an Online Search Machine, Part 4: Telecommunications and Crosstalk XVI,”Online, 9 (July, 1985), pp. 27–34.

Users who have already installed two serial ports cannot use Reach! without disabling one of them, a process that may require technical modifications to circuitry. In such cases I recommend, the purchase of an external modem rather than an internal modem, which can use an existing RS-232 port.
Those whosepcs are already stuffed with expansion boards will be pleased to know that Reach! fits into a short (5.25″) internal slot.
Emulated are Televideo 910/920, IBM 3101, ADDS Viewpoint,dec vt-100 andvt-52, and Texas Instruments 940.

title: A system for interactive encoding of music scores under computer control

reference.author: Stefan M. Kostka
reference.unstructured: For relevant writings, see Stefan M. Kostka,A Bibliography of Computer Applications in Music. Hackensack, NJ: Joseph Boonin, Inc., 1974; and Marc Battier and Jacques Arveiller,Musique et Informatique: une Bibliographie Indexe. Paris: University of Paris, 1976. See also the article by Harry Lincoln, “Use of the Computer in Music Research: A Short Report on Accomplishments, Limitations, and Future Needs,”Computers and the Humanities, 8, 5–6 (1974), 285–289.
reference.volume-title: A Bibliography of Computer Applications in Music

reference.author: David S. Prerau
reference.unstructured: Optical encoding devices have been employed to create a digital copy of a score, i.e., a matrix of data points representing the score. The matrix is then processed to determine the specific symbols and their location, and these symbols are converted to computer-usable code. Because of the complexity of music scores, particularly their two-dimensional nature, optical encoding of scores will demand much more experimentation and probably the development of relatively low-cost special purpose equipment before it will be practical. For reports of experiments in optical encoding of music scores, see David S. Prerau, “DO-RE-MI: A Program That Recognizes Music Notation,”Computers and the Humanities, 9, 1 (1975), 25–29; and Gary Wittlich et al., “Non-Physics Measurements on the PEPR System: Seismograms and Music Scores,” inReport to the Oxford Conference on Computer Scanning. Oxford: Nuclear Physics Laboratory (1974), 487–489.

title: Numbers and history: The dilemma of measurement

reference.unstructured: See particularly Clyde H. Coombs,A Theory of Data (New York, 1964), pp. 1–31.

Donald J. Veldman'sFortran Programming for the Behavioral Sciences (New York, 1967) makes clear that even when historians are statistically adept, programs designed for and by behavioral scientists have limited historical applicability. This problem is discussed further in my review of Veldman's study inHistorical Methods Newsletter, 1 (1968), no. 3, pp. 12–13.

On factor analysis see, for example, Hubert M. Blalock, Jr.,Social Statistics (New York, 1960), pp. 383–89. On Guttman scaling, see A. Douglas Price, “Are Southern Democrats Different? An Application of Scale Analysis to Senate Voting Patterns,” in Nelson Polsby, et al., eds.,Politics and Social Life (Boston, 1963), pp. 740–56. Two historical studies employing Guttman scaling are Thomas B. Alexander,Sectional Stress and Party Strength (Nashville, 1967) and Joel H. Silbey,The Shrine of Party (Pittsburgh, 1967). While to some extent both studies ignore the measurement problem, they nevertheless illustrate the potential of statistical models such as Guttman scaling for analyzing historical data.

reference.unstructured: See, for example, R. J. Rummel, “Dimensions of Conflict Behavior Within Nations, 1946–1959,”Journal of Conflict Resolution, 10 (1966), pp. 65–73 and “Understanding Factor Analysis,”ibid., 11 (1967), pp. 440–78.

For a pioneering approach to this problem of inferring stimuli from testimonial evidence see Murray G. Murphey, “An Approach to the Historial Study of National Character,” inContext and Meaning in Cultural Anthropology (New York, 1965), pp. 144–63.
Louis B. Wright and Marian Tinling, eds.,The Secret Diary of William Byrd (Richmond, 1941).

title: The new philology: An old discipline or a new science?

For a discussion of the Videocomp see Gerald O. Walter, “Typesetting,”Scientific American, May 1969, pp. 60–69.

reference.author: Jagjit Singh
reference.unstructured: Words of caution are to be found in Jagjit Singh, “Physiological Studies and the Computer,”Computer Studies in the Humanities and Verbal Behavior, I (1968), 21–30. Singh argues that it would be beyond present human conception to construct a machine simulating the neural processes. Yet I do not see how we can begin to develop theories relating neural behavior to conceptual and articulatory behavior until we develop theories relating an individual's machine-like use of traditional or formulaic speech patterns to those in which simple or complex rewriting has taken place in the brain.
reference.journal-title: Computer Studies in the Humanities and Verbal Behavior

reference.unstructured: 4 vols., ed. David Packard (Harvard University Press, 1968).
Described inRevue (Organisation internationale pour l'étude des langues anciennes) 1966, No. 2, pp. 17–46.

There is a preliminary report inLiterary Data Processing Conference, pp. 230–274. That report is followed by an account of the program used in collecting Raben's data: Seymour Goodman and Raymond D. Villani, “An Algorithm for Locating Multiple-Word Co-occurrences in Two Sets of Texts,” pp. 275–292.

It is difficult to come by an up-to-date description of this field. Perhaps best known areReadings in Automatic Language Processing, ed. David G. Hays (New York, 1966); David G. Hays,Introduction to Computational Linguistics (New York, 1967); Harold Borko, ed.,Automated Language Processing (New York, 1967); Paul L. Garvin and Bernard Spolsky,Computation in Linguistics: A Case Book (Bloomington, 1966). A textbook is promised us by Bruce Fraser of the Language Research Foundation, Cambridge, Mass., and the proceedings of the Third International Conference on Computational Linguistics, currently available as preprints, give a good overview of the field.

Among the attempts known to me are Paul L. Garvin, Jocelyn Brewer, and Madeleine Mathiot,Predication-Typing: A Pilot Study in Semantic Analysis (Language, 43, ii, 1967-Monograph no. 27, June 1967); Roger Shank and Larry Tesler,A Conceptual Dependency Parser for Natural Language (Stockholm Conference Preprint No. 2, 1969); Ernst von Glaserfield,Semantics and the Syntactic Classification of Words (Stockholm Conference Preprint No. 22, 1969).

B. Vauquois,Le Système de Traduction automatique du C.E.T.A. (Grenoble, 1967); id., G. Veillon, Nedobejkine, and C. Bourguignon,Une Notation des Textes hors des Contraintes morphologiques et syntaxiques de l'Expression (Stockholm Conference Preprint No. 17, 1969); and other publications available to linguists directly from C.E.T.A. A. Zholkovskii and I. Mel'chuk, “O semanticheskom Sintekse”,Problemy Kibernetiki, 19 (1967), pp. 177–238; id.,Essai d'une théorie sémantique applicable au traitement de langage (Annals of the Grenoble Conference, 1967); A. V. Gladky and I.A. Mel'chuk,Tree Grammars (Δ-Grammars) (Stockholm Conference Preprints 1969).

Among the machine programs applied to the analysis of English phrase structure or to generating English sentences are the MITRE Syntactic Analysis Procedure, the Berkeley Parser, and the Harvard Predictive Analyser (seeCommunications of the ACM, July 1965, pp. 453–62. The failure to make progress with machine translation from or into English led to some pessimism (e.g., Y. Bar-Hillel,Language and Information III Addison-Wesley, Reading, Mass., 1964). A number of linguists began searching for economical ways of parsing English on a limited scale, with no thought of machine translation (e.g., D. C. Clarke and R. E. Wall, “An Economic Program for Limited Parsing of English,”Proceedings of the Fall Joint Computer Confernece, 1965, pp. 307–16). Susumu Kuno surveyed the field in an important article: “Computer Analysis of Natural Languages,”Proceedings of Symposia in Applied Mathematics, vol. 19:Mathematical Aspects of Computer Science, 1967, pp. 52–110). At Edinburgh University, James P. Thorne, P. Bratley, and H. Dewar, have produced a syntactic analysis of English by machine (described inCognitive Processes: Methods and Models, pp. 173–181, 281–309. The program was designed to investigate the hearer's recognition of syntactic patterns, but it is also able to “assign syntactic labels to an infinite number of words while operating with a finite dictionary” (p. 281). Daniel G. Bobrow and Bruce Fraser have since produced a more rigorous progrma, STAP, which is able to follow all possible branches forced by formal ambiguity until the correct parsing (or all formally possible parsing) is found and assigned to the constituent items. STAP is described in their article “An Augmented State Transition Network Analysis Procedure” inProceedings of the Joint Conference on Artificial Intelligence (Washington, D.C., 1969). For an approach to testing transformational grammars see Joyce Friedman'sReports from the Stanford Computational Linguistics Project.

reference.unstructured: NotablyHistorical Methods Newsletter: Quantitative Analysis of Social, Economic, and Political Development, published since Dec., 1967, by the history department of the University of Pittsburgh; and the newJournal of Interdisciplinary History, published by M.I.T. Press (1970- ).

reference.author: William O. Aydelotte
reference.unstructured: William O. Aydelotte, “Quantification in History,”American Historical Review 71 (Apr., 1966):803–25; Jacob M. Price, “Recent Quantitative Work in History: A Survey of the Main Trends,”History and Theory, Studies in the Philosophy of History, Beiheft 9 (1969):1–13; Richard Jensen and Charles M. Dollar,Quantitative Historical Research (New York, 1970); Don K. Rowney and James Q. Graham, ed.,Quantitative History: Selected Readings in the Quantitative Analysis of Historical Data (Homewood, Ill., 1969); and Robert P. Swierenga, ed.,Quantification in American History: Theory and Research (New York, 1970). The literature of comment is inCHum, Historical Methods Newsletter, Edmund A. Bowles, ed.,Computers in Humanistic Research: Readings and Perspectives (Englewood Cliffs, 1967), and the items cited above in this note.

A sound critique on the theoretical level is Robert F. Berkhofer, Jr.,A Behavioral Approach to Historical Analysis (New York, 1969). See also Dwight W. Hoover, “Political Behavioralism in American History: A Case Study,”Indiana Academy of the Social Sciences, Proceedings, 1967, Third Series 2 (1967):144–60; George G. S. Murphy, “Historical Investigation and Automatic Data Processing Equipment,”CHum 3, 1 (Sept. 1968):1–13; Arthur M. Schlesinger, Jr., “The Humanist Looks at Empirical Social Research,”American Sociological Review 27 (Dec. 1962):768–71. New Left Historians have largely rejected the social sciences and the new statistical methodology but they have not yet published any major critiques. Urwin Unger, “The ‘New Left’ and American History: Some Recent Trends in United States Historiography,”American Historical Review 62 (July 1967):1262.

reference.author: Robert P. Swierenga
reference.unstructured: The publications, discussed below, are Robert P. Swierenga, “Land Speculator ‘Profits’ Reconsidered: Central Iowa as a Test Case,”Journal of Economic History 27 (Mar. 1966):1–28; Theodore K. Rabb, “Investments in English Overseas Enterprise, 1575–1630,”Economic History Review, Second Series 19 (Apr. 1966):70–81; Thomas B. Alexander, et al., “The Basis of Alabama's Ante-Bellum Two-Party System,”Alabama Review 19 (Oct. 1966):243–76. The dissertations are: Charles M. Dollar, “The Senate Progressive Movement, 1921–1933: A Roll Call Analysis” (Ph.D. diss., University of Kentucky, 1966); and Richard E. Beringer, “Political Factionalism in the Confederate Congress” (Ph.D. diss., Northwestern University, 1966).
Theodore K. Rabb,Enterprise and Empire: Merchant and Gentry Investment in the Expansion of England, 1575–1630 (Cambridge, 1967), p. 133.

A brief discussion of computerized historical research in Europe is “New Ways in History,”The Times Literary Supplement, Apr. 7, Sept. 8, 1966. See especially the essays of J. Kahk, Louis Chevalier, and Keith Thomas.

reference.author: James J. Sheehan
reference.unstructured: James J. Sheehan, “Conference on Quantitative Data in Western European History: A Report,”CHum 3 (Jan. 1969):114–16.

Duncan MacRae, Jr.,Dimensions of Congressional Voting: A Statistical Study of the House of Representatives in the Eighty-first Congress (Berkeley, 1958). The best manual is Lee F. Anderson, et al.,Legislative Roll-Call Analysis (Evanston, 1966).

For partial results see “Parties and Issues in Early Victorian England,”Journal of British Studies 5 (May, 1966):95–101; “The Country Gentlemen and the Repeal of the Corn Laws,”English Historical Review 82 (Jan. 1967):47–60; “The Conservative and Radical Interpretations of Early Victorian Social Legislation,”Victorian Studies 11 (1967):225–36. Aydelotte's methodological caution flag is also waved clearly by George Murphy, “Historical Investigation,” pp. 4–5.

The best known noncomputerized scale study, which probably exemplifies the limits to which sheer determined effort can carry roll-call research without mechanical aids, is Joel H. Silbey,The Shrine of Party: Congressional Voting Behavior, 1841–1852 (Pittsburgh, 1967).
Sectional Stress and Party Strength: A Study of Roll-Call Voting Patterns in the United States House of Representatives, 1836–1860 (Nashville, 1967).

reference.author: Jensen
reference.unstructured: Jensen's review ofSectional Stress and Party Strength is inLouisiana History 7 (Fall, 1967):393–95, reprinted inHistorical Methods Newsletter 1 (Mar. 1968):8–9. George Murphy raises an additional point concerning the randomness of Alexander's sectional pattern (Murphy, “Historical Investigation,” p. 4), and Robert Zemsky questions the comparability of scale scores over time (review inCHum 4 (May 1970):372–73).
reference.journal-title: Sectional Stress and Party Strength is in Louisiana History

reference.author: Bogue
reference.unstructured: Bogue's study is in progress. For example, the anti-Nebraska Representatives held caucuses the night before the votes were taken and agreed not to participate. This decision, if carried through, would have left the House without a quorum. In the end, however, the tactic failed as most of the Democrats, both for and against the Nebraska Bill, showed up and voted. See theNew Orleans Times Picayune, May 10, 1854, Washington Correspondent, May 8, 1854. The opposition also raised petty points of order and demanded a vote count on each motion to set aside the bills, even though they knew the situation was hopeless. reference.unstructured: There was one exception to this. Although most of the some one hundred and fifty roll-calls whose content was directly related to the Kansas-Nebraska Bill did scale with the final vote taken on the Kansas-Nebraska Bill, it was decided that it would be more productive, in this analysis, to exclude them. Instead, we have used only those issues that were not directly related to the Nebraska Bill in their content, and yet still revealed a strong scale relationship with the last vote taken on that measure.
Aydelotte, “Voting Patterns in the British House of Commons in the 1840's,” 141.

reference.author: Louis Guttman
reference.unstructured: The problem was to find some general variable or variables reflected by the scale that were significant enough to have determined the votes of the Representatives on each separate roll-call. The most common use and value of Guttman scaling is based, to a great extent, upon the idea that each scale contains a “universe of attributes,” or a collection of characteristics whose content combines to form one general, overall concept. The existence or absence of such a concept must be established before anything else can be done with a scale. See Louis Guttman, “The Basis of Scalogram Analysis,” in Samuel Stouffer et. al.,Measurement and Prediction, Vol. IV:Studies in Social Psychology in World War II (Princeton, NJ: Princeton University Press, 1950), pp. 80 and 83.
reference.volume-title: Measurement and Prediction, Vol. IV:Studies in Social Psychology in World War II

See Wolff, “The Kansas-Nebraska Bill and Congressional Voting Behavior,” 174–222.

The Democrats who did reject the measure and entered into the debates on the question were Thomas Hart Benton of Missouri and Rufus Peckham and Bishop Perkins of New York, both of whom were “barn-burners.” Benton, it would seem, was mainly concerned with the boost the Gadsden Purchase would give to the southern route for a Pacific railroad. All three men, however, were bitter foes of the Pierce administration, and appear to have been motivated in their negative attitude by this factor. See U.S.Congressional Globe, 33rd Congress, 1st Session, 1854, XXIII, Pt. 2, 1541, 1563, 1565, 1545–1546, 1548; Ibid., Appendix, 1028–1037; Robert Russel,The Improvement of Communication with the Pacific Coast as an Issue in American Politics, 1783–1884 (Cedar Rapids, IA: Torch Press, 1948), pp. 148–149.

reference.unstructured: Ibid.; Madison A. See also Roy F. Nichols,Franklin Pierce (Philadelphia: University of Pennsylvania Press, 1968), pp. 216ff. and Roy F. (New York: Columbia University, Longmans, Green, and Company, Agents; and London: P. S. King and Son, Ltd.), pp. 170ff.

reference.unstructured: The three Whigs who spoke during the debates were John L. Taylor of Ohio, Solomon Haven of New York, and Israel Washburn of Maine. See U.S.Congressional Globe, 33rd Congress, 1st Session, 1854, XXIII, Pt. 2, 1520, 1523–1524, 1537–1543, 1546–1547, 1549: Russel,Improvement of Communication with the Pacific Coast, 147–149.
Washington Union, June 8, 1854.
U.S.Congressional Globe, 33rd Congress, 1st Session, 1854, XXIII, Pt. 2, 1360–1363, 1382.

See Ibid. The only Northern Whigs who spoke during the debates were Solomon Haven of New York, Samuel Parker of Indiana, and Lewis Campbell of Ohio. None of these gentlemen revealed anything meaningful about why they took the position they did, and no other evidence, as far as we know, is available.
Ibid.
U.S.Congressional Globe, 33rd Congress, 2nd Session, 1855, XXIII, 837.

The French Spoliation claims were against the United States government, although they had originally been against France. The claims involved illegal seizures and condemnations of American vessels by the French prior to the treaty that the United States had signed with France in September of 1800. In that treaty of 1800, the United States assumed those claims in exchange for a release from the 1778 Franco-American treaties of alliance. Before the treaty of 1800 was negotiated, the United States set the spoliation claims at approximately twenty million francs. As the years went by, however, the claimants continued to go unpaid. Since the claims were legitimate and the pressure to satisfy the claimants was great, the issue could not be avoided forever. By 1855, Congress was ready to pass such a bill. Pierce, however, decided to veto the measure, and Congress could not override it. See U.S.Congressional Globe, 33rd Congress, 2nd Session, 1855, XXIII, 372–432, 648, 796, 801–818; Ibid., App., 116–128, 141–148, 262–266;Detroit Free Press, February 13, 1855; Thomas Bailey,A Diplomatic History of the American People (New York: Appleton-Century-Crofts, Inc., 1858), p. 98.

For a list of the other seventeen bills that were tabled on this occasion, see U.S.Congressional Globe, 33rd Congress, 1st Session, 1854, XXIII, Pt. 2, 1130–1133. Because of a lack of evidence, it is not possible to know whether there were political maneuverings involved in tabling these other seventeen bills. Perhaps other types of arrangements were made with the supporters of these other measures. However, the French Spoliations Bill is the only one of these issues where there is any evidence that a political deal might have been or needed to be worked out in order to postpone its consideration. For that reason, we must be content, for now, to deal with only this bill.

Philadelphia Public Ledger, April 25, 1854, Washington Correspondent, Arpil 23, 1854. Francis P. Blair, even as early as February 1854, also saw a relationship between the French Spoliations Bill and the Kansas-Nebraska legislation. F. P. Blair to William Allen, February 10, 1854, quoted in Reginald McGrane,William Allen, A Study in Western Democracy (Columbus, OH: Ohio State Archaeological and Historical Society, 1925), pp. 136–137.
Philadelphia Public Ledger, April 25, 1854, Washington Correspondent, April 23, 1854.
Ibid.
U.S.Congressional Globe, 33rd Congress, 1st Session, 1854, XXIII, Pt. 2, 1131.
Elihu Washburne to James S. Pike, May 8, 1854, quoted in Pike,First Blows of the Civil War, 224.
U.S.Congressional Globe, 33rd Congress, 2nd Session, 1855, XXIII, 374.
Philadelphia Public Ledger, June 29, 1854, Washington Correspondent, June 27, 1854.
Ibid., February 19, 1855, Washington Correspondent, February 16, 1855.

Perhaps the Southern Whigs were part of the arrangement to which we have already alluded. More than likely, however, the Whig solidarity on this issue was a reflection of their hostility to the Democrats. However, the debates on the French Spoliations question reveal little with respect to the Whig motivation, since those debates mainly involved the struggle over what form the bill was to take and whether the claims were legitimate. Even then, few Whigs participated in this discussion. There seems to be little or no information available in other sources regarding this problem.

title: Data bases and knowledge representation for literary and linguistic studies

reference.author: R. Abelson
reference.unstructured: Abelson, R. (1975), Concepts for representing mundane reality in Plans, in: D. Bobrow and A. Collins, Eds., Representation and Understanding (Academic Press, New York) 273–310. This paper outlines a cognitive simulation which utilizes the previously developed representational framework of scripts and plans of the author.
reference.volume-title: Representation and Understanding

reference.author: J. Abrial
reference.unstructured: Abrial, J. (1974), Data semantics, in: J. Klimbie and K. Koffeman, Eds., Data Base Management (North-Holland, Amsterdam) 1–60. Motivated by traditional data base models and an inherent bias toward physical storage and retrieval mechanisms, Abrial defines an elaborate model which includes a notation for relations and a notation for operations defined on arbitrary relations. He provides an elaborate example of the model's use, conceding the influence of Codd's relational model and Hewitt'sPlanner. The result is a large collection of abstract ideas suggested as useful for formally specifying data models but suspect as the basis of an implementation.
reference.volume-title: Data Base Management

reference.author: S. Allen
reference.unstructured: Allen, S. (1980), The language bank concept, in: J. Raben and G. Marks, eds., Data Bases in the Humanities and Social Sciences (North-Holland, Amsterdam) 171–176. Allen's paper discusses the theory and practice of a language data bank in the framework for language decoding.
reference.volume-title: Data Bases in the Humanities and Social Sciences

reference.author: J. Anderson
reference.unstructured: Anderson, J. and Bower, G. (1973), Human Associative Memory (Holt, Rinehart and Winston, New York). The book hypothesizes and develops a psychological theory of human memory, including an excellent historical survey of psychological human memory theories.
reference.volume-title: Human Associative Memory

reference.unstructured: Badal D., and Popek, G. (1979), Cost and performance analysis of semantic integrity validations methods, Proceedings ACM SIGMOD, 109–115. Badal and Popek discuss methods for monitoring database integrity validations semantically and compare and contrast their costs and performance.

reference.author: F. Black
reference.unstructured: Black, F. (1968), A deductive question-answering system, in: M. Minsky, Ed., Semantic Information Processing (MIT Press, Cambridge, MA) 354–402. One of the first relatively comprehensive question-answering programs, Black's system predated most of the searchstrategy heuristics developed by theorem-proving research. His question-answering system formally realizes some goals of McCarthy's (1968) ‘advice taker’ proposal.
reference.volume-title: Semantic Information Processing

reference.author: D. Bobrow
reference.unstructured: Bobrow, D. (1975), Dimensions of representation, in: D. Bobrow and A. Collins, Eds., Representation and Understanding (Academic Press, New York) 1–34. Bobrow's paper discusses problems with representing knowledge, e.g., inference mechanisms, matching). He solves some of these problems withKrl-0.
reference.volume-title: Representation and Understanding

reference.author: D. Bobrow
reference.unstructured: Bobrow, D., and Winograd, T. (1977), an overview ofKrl, a Knowledge Representation Language, Cognitive Sci. 1, 3–46. The authors' first report onKrl-0, a knowledge representation language. Significant changes were subsequently made to the formalism reported in this paper.

reference.author: R. Brachman
reference.unstructured: Brachman, R. (1979), On the epistemological status of semantic networks, in: N. Findler, Ed., Associative Networks: Representation and Use of Knowledge by Computers (Academic Press, New York) 3–46. Brachman discusses epistemological primitives in terms of his formalism of “structured inheritance networks” (SI-nets), an elegant formalism which could be considered functionally equivalent to frames, but with a more coherent, explicit semantics.
reference.volume-title: Associative Networks: Representation and Use of Knowledge by Computers

reference.author: R. Brachman
reference.unstructured: Brachman, R. (1978), Theoretical Studies in Natural Language Understanding, Report No. 3888, BBN Inc., Cambridge, MA. A progress report on the development ofKl-one and its potential for representing natural language information.
reference.volume-title: Theoretical Studies in Natural Language Understanding

reference.unstructured: Cercone, N. (1975), Representing Natural Language in Extended Semantic Networks, Ph.D. Thesis, Technical Report TR75-11, Department of Computing Science, University of Alberta. This thesis develops fundamental notation and subsequent logical level use for semantic networks. The structure and computational use of a network-based meaning representation is also reported with results from an experimental implementation.

reference.author: D. Chamberlin
reference.unstructured: Chamberlin, D. (1976), Relational Data Base Management Systems, ACM Computing Surveys 8, 43–66. This paper introduces and surveys relational data base systems.

reference.author: E. Charniak
reference.unstructured: Charniak, E. (1976), Inference and knowledge II, in: E. Charniak and Y. Wilks, Eds., Computational Semantics (North-Holland, Amsterdam) 129–154. This paper reviews the inferential contribution of the author's Ph.D. thesis. It details some classes of inference and outlines the computational machinery necessary to support this type of inference.
reference.volume-title: Computational Semantics

reference.unstructured: Codd, E. (1979), Extending the Relational Data Base Model, Supplement to Proceedings of ACM SIGMOD 1979, 29–52. This report extends the author's original relational data base model.

reference.author: R. Davis
reference.unstructured: Davis, R. (1976), Applications of Meta-level Knowledge to the Construction, Maintenance, and Use of Large Knowledge Bases, Stanford AI Lab Memo AIM-283, Stanford, CA. Davis' doctoral dissertation concerns the automatic acquisition of knowledge for use by expert problem solvers (e.g.,Mycin, Shortliffe (1976)). Davis emphasizes the use of metaknowledge in a program which interacts with a human to capture expert knowledge.
reference.volume-title: Applications of Meta-level Knowledge to the Construction, Maintenance, and Use of Large Knowledge Bases

reference.author: R. Davis
reference.unstructured: Davis, R., Buchanan, B., and Shortliffe, E. (1975), Production rules as a representation for a knowledge based consultation system, Artificial Intelligence 8, 15–45. Focusing on the representation and design of the implementation, this description of theMycin system emphasizes the value of production-rule systems.

reference.author: R. Davis
reference.unstructured: Davis, R., and King, J. (1977), An overview of production systems, in: E. Elcock and D. Michie, Eds., Machine Intelligence 8 (Ellis Horwood, London) 300–332. This survey summarizes the salient features of production systems: their use for several diverse applications exposes their generality but attests to their lack of a well-defined data model.
reference.volume-title: Machine Intelligence 8

reference.author: J. Doyle
reference.unstructured: Doyle, J. (1978), Truth Maintenance Systems for Problem Solving, AI Lab Memo TR-419, MIT, Cambridge, MA. A system for maintaining the consistency of a set of beliefs, and summarizing explanations of beliefs is based on hierarchical decomposition of dependent beliefs and dependency-directed backing up. Also discussed are the problems of representing information to facilitate the application of such a truth maintenance system.
reference.volume-title: Truth Maintenance Systems for Problem Solving

reference.author: M. Eisinger
reference.unstructured: Eisinger, M. (1980), On a vocabulary database, Computers and the Humanities 14, 49–56. This paper describes a system of “storage and retrieval of lemmatized words” designed for Nahuatl.

reference.author: S. Fahlman
reference.unstructured: Fahlman, S. (1979),Netl: A System for Representing and Using Real World Knowledge, MIT Press, Cambridge, MA. In Fahlman'sNetl representation language and its underlying meaning-representation structure, the use of hierarchical organizations is stressed. Making a virtual copy of concept properties is presented as an efficient property-inheritance mechanism. Fahlman's parallel concept network hardware provides a foundation forNetl data structures, improving the efficiency of data base operations.
reference.volume-title: Netl: A System for Representing and Using Real World Knowledge

reference.author: E. Feigenbaum
reference.unstructured: Feigenbaum, E. (1977), The Art of Artificial Intelligence: Themes and Case Studies of Knowledge Engineering, Proceedings of IJCAI 5, Cambridge, MA, 1014–1029. An invited lecture at IJCAI 5, this paper discusses some of the important major systems contributions to AI in the last 10 years.
reference.volume-title: The Art of Artificial Intelligence: Themes and Case Studies of Knowledge Engineering

reference.author: E. Feigenbaum
reference.unstructured: Feigenbaum, E., Buchanan, B., and Lederberg, J. (1971), On generality and problem solving: A case study using theDendral program, in: B. Meltzer and D. Michie, Eds., Machine Intelligence 6 (American Elsevier, New York) 165–189. A discussion of the design and performance of the heuristicDendral system investigates the interaction between expert knowledge and general problem-solving within the production rule based expert system.
reference.volume-title: Machine Intelligence 6

reference.author: N. Findler
reference.unstructured: Findler, N. (1979), Associative Networks: Representation and Use of Knowledge by Computers (Academic Press, New York). In this special volume, a comprehensive overview of associative network representations of knowledge, fourteen contributions are grouped according to three criteria: overview and general systems, theoretically oriented efforts and areas of application.
reference.volume-title: Associative Networks: Representation and Use of Knowledge by Computers

reference.author: J. Fry
reference.unstructured: Fry, J., and Sibley, E. (1976), Evolution of Data-Base Management Systems, ACM Computing Surveys 8, 7–42. The paper provides an excellent starting point for the study of the history and objectives of data base management systems.

reference.author: H. Gallaire
reference.unstructured: Gallaire, H., and Minker, J. (1978), Logic and Data Bases (Plenum Press, New York). The edited proceedings of the conference on Logic and Data Bases held in Toulouse, France, in November 1977 advocates the use of logic as the basis for data base management systems.
reference.volume-title: Logic and Data Bases

reference.author: P. Gilmore
reference.unstructured: Gilmore, P. (1971), A Consistent Naive Set Theory: Foundations for a Formal Theory of Computation, IBM Research Report RC 3413, Yorktown Heights, New York. A second-order theory permitting universal quantification and unlimited set abstraction, like the one described here, may ultimately be required as the basis for an AI data model.
reference.volume-title: A Consistent Naive Set Theory: Foundations for a Formal Theory of Computation, IBM Research Report RC 3413

reference.author: R. Goebel
reference.unstructured: Goebel, R. (1977), Organising Factual Knowledge in a Semantic Network, TR77-8, Department of Computing Science, University of Alberta, Edmonton, Alberta. The author's M.Sc. thesis defines and reports results of an implementation of a method for organising knowledge in a semantic network.
reference.volume-title: Organising Factual Knowledge in a Semantic Network, TR77-8

reference.author: L. Green
reference.unstructured: Green, L., Berkeley, E., and Gotlieb, C.C. (1959), Conversation with a computer, Computers and Automation 8, 9–11. This is a very early system which answered questions about the weather.

reference.author: B. Green
reference.unstructured: Green, B., Wolf, A., Chomsky, C., and Laugherty, K. (1963),Baseball: An automatic question-answerer, in: E. Feigenbaum and J. Feldman, Eds., Computers and Thought (McGraw-Hill, New York) 207–216.Baseball is a computer program written in IPL-V, and operating in a limited context with a small vocabulary and simple attribute-value pair data that suffices for a more detailed representation; it answers questions posed in ordinary English about data in its store.
reference.volume-title: Computers and Thought

reference.unstructured: Hammer, M., and Sarin, S. (1978), Efficient monitoring of database assertions, Proceedings ACM SIGMOD, 38–49. Hammer and Sarin discuss effective methods for monitoring database assertions under additions and deletions of the database.

Havens, W. (1977). A Procedural Model of Recognition for Machine Perception, Ph.D. thesis, University of British Columbia, TR78-3. This work discusses the merits of combining the top-down and bottom-up programming paradigms as they are applied to the computer recognition of physical objects.

Hayes, P. (1977), In Defence of Logic, Proceedings of IJCAI 5, Cambridge, MA., 559–565. Explaining why semantics is important, Hayes discusses several misconceptions about the use of logical representations. He suggests that the logical notion of meaning should be taken more seriously.

reference.author: P. Hayes
reference.unstructured: Hayes, P. (1977b), The Logic of Frames, Department of Computer Science, University of Essex, U.K. Hayes suggests various logical interpretations of frame knowledge including a logical rendering ofKrl-0's ‘units’. He concludes that the contribution of frames may be their apparent capacity to encode reflexive knowledge.
reference.volume-title: The Logic of Frames

reference.author: P. Hayes
reference.unstructured: Hayes, P. (1974), Some Issues and Non-Issues in Representation Theory, Proceedings of the AISB Summer Conference, University of Sussex, U.K. 63–79. Hayes clearly articulates the major issues of representation theory, emphasizing the semantics of a representation and the representation's flexibility for accommodating new information. Issues of representing substances and sub-parts, and issues involved in representing control information are discussed.
reference.volume-title: Some Issues and Non-Issues in Representation Theory

reference.author: G. Hendrix
reference.unstructured: Hendrix, G. (1975), Expanding the Utility of Semantic Networks Through Partitioning, Proceedings of IJCAI 4, Tbilisi, USSR, 115–121. Hendrix proposes a quantification mechanism for semantic network concepts and introduces formal groupings of concept nodes which he calls partitions.
reference.volume-title: Expanding the Utility of Semantic Networks Through Partitioning, Proceedings of IJCAI 4

reference.author: C. Hewitt
reference.unstructured: Hewitt, C. (1977), Viewing Control Structures as Patterns of Passing Messages, Artificial Intelligence 8, 323–364. The paper is intended as background to a proposed system which operates in a parallel computing environment. Hewitt describes an intelligent system as a society of communicating knowledge-based problem-solving experts. The control mechanisms necessary to facilitate communication in such a system are described and some (e.g., iteration and recursion) are represented in terms of patterns of messages exchanged between actors.

reference.author: C. Hewitt
reference.unstructured: Hewitt, C. (1972), Description and Theoretical Analysis (using schemata) ofPlanner: A Language for Proving Theorems and Manipulating Models in a Robot, AI Lab Memo TR-258, MIT, Cambridge, MA. Hewitt's dissertation describes the development ofPlanner, outlining its components with pseudo-code and English description.
reference.volume-title: Description and Theoretical Analysis (using schemata) ofPlanner: A Language for Proving Theorems and Manipulating Models in a Robot, AI Lab Memo TR-258

reference.unstructured: Hewitt, C., Bishop, P., and Steiger, R. (1973), A Universal ACTOR Formalism for Artificial Intelligence, PROCEEDINGS OF IJCAI 3, Stanford, CA, 235–245. In discussing the universality of theactor ‘formalism’ implemented inPlanner, the authors assert that actors provide a formalism for procedural semantics.
Hobbs, J. (1977), Coherence and Interpretation in English Texts, PROCEEDINGS OF IJCAI 5, Cambridge, MA, 110–116. A thorough investigation of coherence in English texts.

reference.author: J. Huntsman
reference.unstructured: Huntsman, J. (1980), The state of lexicography and lexicology in Plantagenet England: A data base, in: J. Raben and G. Marks, Eds., Data Bases in the Humanities and Social Sciences (North-Holland, Amsterdam) 197–203. This paper describes the computational techniques used to incorporate textual characteristics of manuscripts in British libraries into a data base designed to facilitate future literary research.
reference.volume-title: Data Bases in the Humanities and Social Sciences

reference.author: R. Kowalski
reference.unstructured: Kowalski, R. (1977), Logic for Data Description, in: H. Gallaire and J. Minker, Eds., Logic and Data Bases (Plenum Press, New York) 77–103. Kowalski describes how first-order logic is appropriate and powerful for representing data typically handled by a relational data model. He further argues that a logic programming view dissolves the conventional distinction between data bases and programs. He also describes logic programming interpretations for maintaining integrity, accommodating non-monotonic information, and exploiting meta and object level interpretations of logical expressions.
reference.volume-title: Logic and Data Bases

reference.author: H. Kučera
reference.unstructured: Kučera, H., and Francis, W.N. (1967), Computational Analysis of Present-Day American English (Brown University Press, Providence, RI). A one-million-word corpus of present-day edited American English.
reference.volume-title: Computational Analysis of Present-Day American English

reference.author: R. Lindsay
reference.unstructured: Lindsay, R. (1973), In defence of ad-hoc systems, in: R. Schank and K. Colby, Eds., Computer Models of Thought and Language (Freeman, San Francisco) 373–395. An insightful treatment of the notion ‘ad-hoc’ as it relates to three specific problems. Lindsay describes the work of two graduate students, Roger Elliot (problem one) and John Brown (problem two), as well as his efforts to extend their work (problem three). This excellent article lends rigor to the notion of ad-hoc and uses family kinship relations as a domain of discourse.
reference.volume-title: Computer Models of Thought and Language

reference.author: R. Lindsay
reference.unstructured: Lindsay, R. (1963), Inferential memory as the basis of machines which understand natural language, in: E. Feigenbaum and J. Feldman, Eds., Computers and Thought (McGraw-Hill, New York) 217–233. A very early and (by today's standards) tiny system that explored question-answering by machine. The program, limited to an 850-word vocabulary of Basic English, incorporated design features which have subsequently gained acceptance in the AI community, e.g., goal orientation, heuristics in parsing, stress on inference.
reference.volume-title: Computers and Thought

reference.unstructured: McCalla, G. (1977), An Approach to the Organisation of Knowledge for the Modelling of Conversation, Ph.D. thesis, University of British Columbia. Describes |Lisp (‘bar’-Lisp), a proposed programming system to support discourse analysis.

reference.author: J. McCarthy
reference.unstructured: McCarthy, J., and Hayes, P. (1969), Some Philosophical Problems from the Standpoint of Artificial Intelligence, in: B. Meltzer and D. Michie, Eds., Machine Intelligence 4 (American Elsevier, New York) 463–502. This classic paper treats the issues surrounding the development of a formal system for representing and using knowledge in great depth. The distinction between an epistemologically and heuristically adequate representation is drawn and emphasis is given to the former. The problems inherent in formally representing a changing world include meta-knowledge, modalities and time.
reference.volume-title: Machine Intelligence 4

reference.unstructured: McDermott, D. (1978), The last survey of knowledge representation, Proceedings of the AISB/GB Conference on AI, Hamburg, 206–221. A survey of current issues in representation theory with an evaluation of what needs to be done. McDermott emphasizes the development of representation ‘techniques’ and discusses representation in terms of programming, semantics, ‘new’ notations, and managing dynamic data bases.

reference.author: D. McDermott
reference.unstructured: McDermott, D. (1978b), Tarskian semantics, or No Notation Without Denotation, Cognitive Science 2, 277–282. Explaining how denotational semantics is a tool for representation research McDermott defends it against various arguments. The paper is clear and direct, written for those who have yet to discover the utility of denotational semantics. True believers will see in this paper, a “now I'm convinced, what about you guys” attitude, which would be a good introduction to Hayes (1974, 1977).

reference.author: D. McDermott
reference.unstructured: McDermott, D. and Doyle, J. (1979), Non-Monotonic Logic I, AI Lab Memo 489A, MIT, Cambridge, MA. Based on logic in which new axioms can invalidate old theorems, a system is proposed as a model of beliefs, and its correspondence to some related systems is discussed.
reference.volume-title: Non-Monotonic Logic I, AI Lab Memo 489A

reference.author: D. McDermott
reference.unstructured: McDermott, D. and Sussman, G. (1974), The Conniver Reference Manual, AI Lab Memo 259A, MIT, Cambridge, MA. A reference manual to the LISP-based programming languageConniver, designed in response to the blind-back-tracking and global-context problems of Micro-Planner.
reference.volume-title: The Conniver Reference Manual, AI Lab Memo 259A

reference.author: J. Meunier
reference.unstructured: Meunier, J. (1983), Formal semantics for interactive computer text processing, Computers and Mathematics 9(1), 147–172. This paper describes a large multi-faceted 12-year project of the Philosophy Department at the University of Quebec, Montreal.

reference.author: M. Minsky
reference.unstructured: Minsky, M. (1975), A framework for representing knowledge, in: P. Winston, Ed., The Psychology of Computer Vision (McGraw-Hill, New York) 211–277. This paper established the vocabulary of frames and frame systems.
reference.volume-title: The Psychology of Computer Vision

reference.author: J. Moore
reference.unstructured: Moore, J., and Newell, A. (1973), How Can Merlin Understand, Department of Computer Science, Carnegie-Mellon University, Pittsburgh. The authors discuss four major issues regarding the scope of representation, i.e., what kind of knowledge can be represented. Problems and solutions are discussed in terms of production systems.
reference.volume-title: How Can Merlin Understand, Department of Computer Science

reference.author: A. Newell
reference.unstructured: Newell, A. (1973), Production Systems: Models of Control Structures, in: W. Chase, Ed., Visual Information Processing (Academic Press, New York) 463–526. Newell explains how production systems can provide a model of control structure in human information processing. Some results from the Sternberg classification experiments, in conjunction with a production system, form a new hypothesis for the search performed during classification.
reference.volume-title: Visual Information Processing

reference.author: J. Nicolas
reference.unstructured: Nicolas, J., and Gallaire, H. (1978), Data bases: Theory vs. interpretation, in: H. Gallaire and J. Minker, Eds., Logic and Data Bases (Plenum Press, New York) 33–54. Three views of how a data base can be viewed as a logical theory emphasize whether general expressions about an extensional data base should be used as derivation rules or as integrity constraints.
reference.volume-title: Logic and Data Bases

reference.author: J. Nicolas
reference.unstructured: Nicolas, J., and Yazdanian, K. (1978), Integrity checking in deductive data bases, in: H. Gallaire and J. Minker, Eds., Logic and Data Bases (Plenum Press, New York) 325–344. When viewed within a particular logic framework, integrity constraints can be classed as logical formulae which deal with either data base transitions or data base static states. The use of each of these classes of constraints is discussed, with emphasis on exploiting their use in logical deduction.
reference.volume-title: Logic and Data Bases

reference.author: D. Ogden
reference.unstructured: Ogden, D. (1933), Basic English (Basic Books, New York). The 850-word subset of English used to teach English as a second language.
reference.volume-title: Basic English

reference.unstructured: Pople, H. (1977), The Formation of Hypothesis in Diagnostic Problem Solving, and Exercise in Synthetic Reasoning, Proceedings IJCAI5, Cambridge, MA, 1030–1037. This paper reports the previous seven years' progress on a major system which William Meyers, a world-renowned diagnostician, believes duplicates his diagnostic abilities.

reference.author: M. Quillian
reference.unstructured: Quillian, M. (1968), Semantic memory, in: M. Minsky, Ed., Semantic Information Processing (MIT Press, Cambridge, MA) 227–270. Quillian builds a network of objects and relations, similar to Raphael's (see below) but less pre-configured. The plausibilities of different interpretations of word concepts are compared through the strengths of the chains linking the various pairs of meanings. Quillian's famous ‘spreading activation’ intersection technique is described.
reference.volume-title: Semantic Information Processing

reference.author: B. Raphael
reference.unstructured: Raphael, B. (1968), SIR: A Computer Program for Semantic Information Retrieval, in: M. Minsky, Ed. (MIT Press, Cambridge, MA) 33–145. Raphael's system builds a memory structure to convert the information it receives into a systematic, efficient representation, a network in which objects are interconnected by a variety of different relations.
reference.volume-title: SIR: A Computer Program for Semantic Information Retrieval

reference.author: R. Reiter
reference.unstructured: Reiter, R. (1980), A logic for default reasoning, Artificial Intelligence 13, 81–132. A default logic is developed to provide a formal system for the maintenance and revision of beliefs. Reiter describes how a wide class of situations which require reasoning by default can be accommodated within a default logic by means of a proof theory based on top-down resolution theorem-proving.

reference.author: R. Roberts
reference.unstructured: Roberts, R., and Goldstein, I. (1977), TheFrl Manual, AI Lab Memo 409, MIT, Cambridge, MA. This is a reference manual for the frame-based representation languageFrl implemented inLisp.
reference.volume-title: TheFrl Manual, AI Lab Memo 409

reference.author: J. Rulifson
reference.unstructured: Rulifson, J., Derksen, J., and Waldinger, R. (1972), QA4: A Procedural Calculus for Intuitive Reasoning, AI Note 73, Stanford University, Stanford, CA. A description of one of the early languages designed to support formal reasoning systems based on resolution.
reference.volume-title: QA4: A Procedural Calculus for Intuitive Reasoning, AI Note 73

reference.author: D. Rumelhart
reference.unstructured: Rumelhart, D., Lindsay, P., and Norman, D. (1972), A Process Model for Long Term Memory, in: E. Tulving and W. Donaldson, Eds., Organization of Memory (Academic Press, New York) 197–246. The authors describe a system with relatively good performance despite difficulties with their representation. For example, they suggest (without clarifying how it might be done) that adverbials be treated as operators that apply to relations and other operators in order to generate new operators. Unfortunately, many adverbial modifiers require systematic analysis rather than mere replacement by ‘n-valued’ relations, as the autors suggest.
reference.volume-title: Organization of Memory

reference.author: R. Schank
reference.unstructured: Schank, R. (1975), The role of memory in language processing, in: C. Cofer, Ed., The Structure of Human Memory (Freeman, San Francisco) 162–189. The paper explains the use of memory for inference purposes. Some of the notions Schank expressed in this paper were further developed into scripts and plans.
reference.volume-title: The Structure of Human Memory

reference.author: R. Schank
reference.unstructured: Schank, R. (1972), Conceptual dependency: A theory of natural language understanding, Cognitive Psychology 3, 552–631. This is the definitive paper explaining conceptual dependency theory.

reference.author: R. Schank
reference.unstructured: Schank, R., Goldman, N., Rieger, C., and Riesbeck, C. (1973),Margie: Memory Analysis, Response Generation and Inference in English, Proceedings of IJCAI 3, 255–261. A comprehensive report on the use of conceptual dependency in theMargie system. The (then) twelve primitive acts and their inferences are used as the basis of analyzing the meaning of isolated sentences. Several different types of inferences are distinguished and the strucutre of memory which facilitates these inferences is emphasized.

reference.author: L. Schubert
reference.unstructured: Schubert, L. (1976), Extending the expressive power of semantic networks, Artificial Intelligence 7 (2), 163–198. This definitive paper extends the expressive power of conventional semantic network notation. The special problems with respect to the use of logical connectives, quantifiers, descriptions, and certain other constructions are solved by systematically extending the more or less conventional notation.

reference.author: L. Schubert
reference.unstructured: Schubert, L., Goebel, R., and Cercone, N. (1979), The structure and organisation of a semantic net for comprehension and inference, in: N. Findler, Ed., Associative Networks: The Representation and Use of Knowledge by Computers (Academic Press, New York) 121–175. This summary of the last four years' effort of the authors discusses semantic network level representation in great detail and reinforces design decisions by a logical analysis. Also presented are two mini-implementations as results and some speculation about the future direction of this research.
reference.volume-title: Associative Networks: The Representation and Use of Knowledge by Computers

reference.unstructured: Sciore, E. (1979), Improving Semantic Specification in a Relational Database, Proceedings of ACM SIGMOD 1979, Boston, 170–178. An axiomatization of renaming rules is proposed as a method of formally specifying the relationships among the relational data model attributes. The resulting application of this axiomatization to a relational data model results in a characterization of relations orthogonal to the traditional one; the author speculates that it may provide another heuristic to help determine useful normal forms of a relational data base.
Scragg, W. (1975), Frames, Planes, Nets: A Synthesis, Working Paper 19, Istituto per gli Studi Semantici e Cognitivi, Castagnola, Switzerland. This is exactly what the title suggests—a working paper.

Shapiro, S. (1971), A Net Structure for Semantic Storage, Deduction, and Retrieval, Proceedings of IJCAI 2, London, 512–523. This early treatment of semantic networks made the important distinction between the ‘item’ (conceptual level of network) and the ‘system’ (implementation level of network).

reference.author: E. Shortliffe
reference.unstructured: Shortliffe, E. (1976), Computer Based Medical Consultations:Mycin (American Elsevier, New York). A description of theMycin system.
reference.volume-title: Computer Based Medical Consultations:Mycin

reference.author: R. Simmons
reference.unstructured: Simmons, R., Klein, S., and McConologue, K. (1964), Maximum depth indexing for computer retrieval of English language data, American Documentation 15, 196–204. A report onProtosynthex which represents one of the novel early efforts to construct a reasonable question-answering system.

reference.author: B. Smith
reference.unstructured: Smith, B., and Brachman, R. (1977), How is a Knowledge Representation System Like a Piano, AI Lab Memo 497, MIT, Cambridge, MA. A very comprehensive questionnaire soliciting views on nearly every aspect of representation. The responses were intended to be produced as a special issue of the ACM's Special Interest Group on AI [SIGART].
reference.volume-title: How is a Knowledge Representation System Like a Piano, AI Lab Memo 497

reference.author: R. Stallman
reference.unstructured: Stallman, R., and Sussman, G. (1979), Forward reasoning and dependency-directed backtracking in a system for computer-aided circuit analysis, Artificial Intelligence 9, 135–196. An interesting application of the use ofPlanner and actor-like inference mechanisms with a specialized data base of electric circuit jargon.

Stonebreaker, M. (1979), The Argument Against CODASYL, Supplement to the Proceedings of ACM SIGMOD, Boston, 58–62. A persuasive argument against using the CODASYL DBTG report as the basis of data base models.

reference.author: G. Sussman
reference.unstructured: Sussman, G., Winograd, T., and Charniak, E. (1971), Micro-Planner Reference Manual, AI Lab Memo 203A, MIT, Cambridge, MA. A reference manual for theLisp-based programming language based on a subset of Hewitt's (1972)Planner language.
reference.volume-title: Micro-Planner Reference Manual, AI Lab Memo 203A

reference.author: P. Szolovits
reference.unstructured: Szolovits, P., Hawkison, L., and Martin, W. (1977), An Over view of owl: A Language for Knowledge Representation, MIT/LCS/TM-86, MIT, Cambridge, MA. An overview ofOwl, whose language-specific primitive elements are expressions based on English. The authors view their “Linguistic Memory System” as a semantic network.
reference.volume-title: An Over view of owl: A Language for Knowledge Representation

reference.author: M. Emden Van
reference.unstructured: Van Emden, M. (1977), Programming with resolution logic, in: E. Elcock and D. Michie, Eds., Machine Intelligence 8 (Ellis Horwood, London) 266–299. The use of ‘resolution logic’ as a programming tool is discussed, particularly automatic programming and logic-based syntactic analyses.
reference.volume-title: Machine Intelligence 8

reference.author: D. Waterman
reference.unstructured: Waterman, D. (1970), Generalized learning techniques for automating the learning of heuristics, Artificial Intelligence 1, 121–170. Waterman describes the implementation and use of a program which develops heuristics for poker betting. A production system component facilitates modular replacement and refinement of the rules by a companion learning component. The program learns by a training process (cf. Winston'sArch program) or by playing a human opponent.

reference.author: B. Webber
reference.unstructured: Webber, B. (1982), Extended Natural Language Database Interaction, Proceedings of the Fourth CSCSI/SCEIO National Conference, Saskatoon, Canada. Webber discusses the extent to which a natural language ‘front-end’ can be useful in a data base system. Examples are drawn from a student data base.
reference.volume-title: Extended Natural Language Database Interaction, Proceedings of the Fourth CSCSI/SCEIO National Conference

reference.author: Y. Wilks
reference.unstructured: Wilks, Y. (1977), Good and Bad Arguments about Semantic Primitives, D.A.I. Research Report No. 42, University of Edinburgh, Edinburgh. Wilks reviews some arguments for and against the belief in and use of semantic primitives. While the arguments are somewhat muddled, his conclusions, albeit non-committal, are sound: primitives are useful in natural language understanding systems whether or not they ‘exist’ in principle.
reference.volume-title: Good and Bad Arguments about Semantic Primitives, D.A.I. Research Report No. 42

reference.author: Y. Wilks
reference.unstructured: Wilks, Y. (1973), Preference Semantics, Stanford AI Project, memo AIM-206, Stanford University, Stanford, CA. The most referenced of Wilks' papers nicely describes the overall system of preference semantics from the sixty or so semantic primitives to the intricacies of the processing programs.
reference.volume-title: Preference Semantics, Stanford AI Project, memo AIM-206

reference.author: K. Wilson
reference.unstructured: Wilson, K. (1979), From Association to Structure (North-Holland, Amsterdam). Wilson argues for an associative theory which can account for the development and use of natural language. An engaging series of arguments suggests that much of cognitive psychology operates with cognitive models which rely on a priori knowledge, rather than embodying any learning capacity.
reference.volume-title: From Association to Structure

reference.author: T. Winograd
reference.unstructured: Winograd, T. (1976), Towards a Procedural Understanding of Semantics, AI Lab Memo AIM 292, Stanford University, Stanford, CA. Winograd outlines a theory of language production and comprehension based on procedural semantics. He suggests that there is a level of ‘explanation’ at which the psychological processes of human language use and the process in computer programs are sufficiently similar to imply that a procedural semantics can form the basis for such a theory.
reference.volume-title: Towards a Procedural Understanding of Semantics, AI Lab Memo AIM 292

reference.author: T. Winograd
reference.unstructured: Winograd, T. (1972), Understanding Natural Language (Academic Press, New York). Winograd's language understanding program endorses the procedural meaning representation for knowledge due to Hewitt (1971). In his system, which combines many fascinating techniques to produce spectacular results, semantic analysis takes place before syntactic processing is complete. This was the first true integration of semantic and syntactic processing to produce good results. As they relate to a more general understanding paradigm, however, Winograd's methods received many criticisms.
reference.volume-title: Understanding Natural Language

reference.author: H. Wong
reference.unstructured: Wong, H., and Mylopolous, J. (1977), Two views of data semantics: A survey of data models in Artificial Intelligence and Data Base Management, INFOR 15, 344–383. One of the first papers to suggest a comparison of AI data models with DBM data models. A fairly comprehensive treatment of representation ideas, discussed and compared in terms of predicate calculus, network and procedure-based systems. The authors conclude that AI and DBM have so much in common that eventually the apparent differences will evaporate.

reference.author: W. Woods
reference.unstructured: Woods, W. (1975), What's in a link, in: D. Bobrow and A. Collins, Eds., Representation and Understanding (Academic Press, New York) 35–82. This paper raises many issues concerning the foundations of semantic networks and representation in general. Many of the challenges Woods puts forth were treated in Schubert (1976), Brachman (1979) and Schubert et al. (1979).
reference.volume-title: Representation and Understanding

reference.author: W. Woods
reference.unstructured: Woods, W., Kaplan, R., and Nash-Webber, B. (1972), The Lunar Sciences Natural Language Information System: Final Report (Bolt, Beranek and Newman, Cambridge, MA). Woods discusses theLunar program which answers scientist's questions about the moon rocks.
reference.volume-title: The Lunar Sciences Natural Language Information System: Final Report

reference.author: G. P. Zarri
reference.unstructured: Zarri, G. P. (1982), Differences and Similarities between the Two Inference Modes of theReseda System, Proceedings of the Fourth CSCSI/SCEIO National Conference, Saskatoon, Canada, 183–189. Zarri discusses a historical bibliographic data base.
reference.volume-title: Differences and Similarities between the Two Inference Modes of theReseda System, Proceedings of the Fourth CSCSI/SCEIO National Conference

reference.unstructured: IML—the Intermediary Musical Language developed by Hubert Howe and Alexander Jones—is in use at Princeton University. A description of thePlaine and Easie Code System for Musicke may be found in an article by its inventors, Barry S. Brook and Murray Gould, “Notating Music with Ordinary Typewriter Characters,”Fontes Artis Musicae XI (1964), pp. 142–159. DARMS, as the language taught at the Harpur College Music-Computer Seminar, is probably the most widely used of the languages currently available. It was developed by Stefan Bauer-Mengelberg. For a report on the Harpur College Seminar, see James Pruett, “The Harpur College Music-Computer Seminar,”CHum I (1966), pp. 34–38.

reference.unstructured: Scribes frequently were careless about the length of the last note of a section. It was left short so that pick-up notes in the following estribillo could be more easily seen, or held out over into the next measure without consistency. These notes were made consistent with one one another and with the conventions of style.

This representation is being developed by Stefan Bauer-Mengelberg and Raymond F. Erickson. It is highly mnemonic, quickly learned, and capable of representing musical complexities far beyond those encountered in this study.

reference.unstructured: A sample page of the concordance used in this article appears in the Appendix, p. 338.

reference.author: Ralph B. Long
reference.unstructured: Ralph B. Long defines a sentence as: “linguistic units of certain magnitude. On written discourse they are ordinarily the most clearly marked units smaller than paragraphs and larger than words: capital letter begins them, periods or equivalent marks end them, and there is a characteristic spacing before and after. Sometimes a single word can be a sentence, and even a paragraph; but the distinction in magnitude is a real one nevertheless. Most sentences are dependent of the context of preceding sentences or situation for some of their meaning.” Long calls attention in this respect to the unpunctuated 25,000-word reverie at the end of Joyce'sUlysses where one cannot always be sure where the sentence boundaries are. Ralph B. Long.The Sentence and Its Parts: A Grammar of Contemporary English (Chicago: The University of Chicago Press, 1961), p. 9.
reference.volume-title: The Sentence and Its Parts: A Grammar of Contemporary English

reference.author: Jean Roudaut
reference.unstructured: Jean Roudaut, “Robert Pinget et la boussole,”Critique, 303–304 (August–September 1972), 739.

Pinget has described his creative process as “automatic writing” with careful subsequent conscious filtering of multiple existing possibilities. As he wrote, in answer to a request from Professor Henkels for the Preface to the study of his novels soon to appear through the University of Alabama Press, “You have already paid me an unhoped for honor in grappling with my work, which I do not understand very well, as you know. That kind of psychoanalysis, in the long run, which I undertook unwillingly to end up withPassacaille, gives me reason today not to be proud of myself, I assure you.” In a more concrete case of unconscious association unearthed by theFable concordance, in discussion with M. Pinget at his French farmhouse retreat in Touraine in the summer of 1975, we related the findings documented by the concordance and asked him why pigs seemed to keep turning up among the fauna of his most recent works. Somewhat taken aback, he admitted to the presence of the creatures inPassacaille, but stoutly denied that there were any inFable. A check of the concordance did indeed show only a single occurrence of the word “cochon.” The words “porcherie” (pigsty) and “porcher” (swineherd) appeared also, in two dramatic and symbolic instances. Symbolizing the final desecration of the herb garden that sheltered the now-parted lovers, the swineherd drives his animals into an enclosure now used as their wallow: Mais l'autre jetait un coup d'oeil dans la cour et disait lescochons ont franchi la cloture, allez-y mettre bon ordre. Et Miaille se levait, il serait leporcher, et il faisait rentrer les bêtes dans le clos qui n'abriterait plus d'aromates. (p. 63). As it turned out, while writingFable in the country, Pinget (like Nathalie Sarraute, who coincidentally found herself in a similarly malodorous rural situation elsewhere) was in litigation with a neighboring farmer to force him to remove a large, fragrant pig manure pile just upwind of his property. The necessity for this “démarche” became quite apparent during our visit when a breeze came up, and obviously the complex device of repetition and word association had let those pigs slip through Pinget's imagination through the Gates of Horn.

reference.author: Victor Chklovski
reference.unstructured: Although Victor Chklovski deals with this phenomenon inSur la théorie de la prose, Trans. Guy Verret (Laussanne: Editions L'Age d'Homme, 1973), it is more likely that Pinget became aware of it through the works of Max Jacob and the early Surrealists.
reference.volume-title: Sur la théorie de la prose

reference.author: Victor B. Chklovski
reference.unstructured: “Dès qu'on percoit les choses plusieurs fois, la perception commence à operer par reconnaissance: la chose est devant nous, nous le savons, mais nous ne la voyons pas. Et c'est pourquoi nous ne pouvons rien en dire. Pour soustraire une chose à l'automatisme de la perception, l'art dispose de différents moyens....” Victor B. Chklovski,Sur la théorie de la prose, Translation from Russian by Guy Verret (Lausanne: Editions L'Age d'Home, 1973), 17.
reference.volume-title: Sur la théorie de la prose

reference.unstructured: Many other cases of this technique abound in the text. The wordville, for example, appears successively as: “la ville” (p. 10), “ces décombres de laville ...” (p. 11), “Cetteville qui fume encore ...” (p. 12), “Et pourquoi cetteville, ces décombres ...” (p. 14), “il n'y aurait qu'une chambre dans cetteville fumante sous ses décombres ...” (p. 19), “un rapport peutêtre avec l'effondrement de laville ...” (p. 20), “Laville fumante sous ses décombres ...” (p. 25), “Mais laville fumait toujours sous les décombres ...” (p. 38), “Comme il arrivait un matin venant de laville en ruines ...” (p. 50), “Laville avait fondu sous l'effet d'un cataclysme ...” (p. 10, 80), “Parce que sa maison il l'aurait fait avec Louis ... ou bien enville, notre bourg est devenu un endroit de vacances ...” (p. 100), “ils vont dans les bars de laville ...” (p. 101), “C'est l'heure où les vieux soupirent, où les jeunes vont enville ...” (p. 104)

Between pages 67 and 83 l'âme (the soul) is associated with the struggle between conflicting desires for change and stability. In part II, the narrator has blinded himself with a razor slash, “un coup de lame.” This act, apparently an abdication of the desire to see and understand is, in fact, the philosophical act of accepting life that returns the narrator to an uneasy equilibrium, a paradox reinforced by another pun involving “se mirer,” “miroir” and “miro.”

Also exemplifying this technique of playing off repeated action through an iterative verb and the uncertain shifting of moods or tenses is the phrase “refaire le tour”; “Il refaisait le tour de la grange ...” (p. 13), “Il referait le tour des bâtiments à la nuit tombée ...” (p. 59).

By winnowing out the text's numerous allusions to the supernatural, the word frequency list shows to what degree the hope of a salvation remains, not an operative reality, but a hope or dream. In the lexical category of religious belief, nominal constructions outnumber verbal ones 44 to 2. There are several references to Greek myth (most notable the title) and allusions to Proteus and Narcissus. Christian iconography is also invoked with more than passing frequency, “Dieu,” “le Diable,” “Jean Baptiste,” “fruit de vos entrailles,” “Immaculée,” “croix,” “sacré coeur,” among others. At first, the wordange, of Greek origin, seems to bridge the two systems of belief because in the Christian context it indicates a bearer of glad tidings. But the angel's message of Joy never gets through. And, as documented by the frequency tables, salvation is presented stylistically as a thing to be named or invoked, not an acting force.
Robert Pinget, “Le mécanisme de la création littéraire” (lecture), Williams College, April 20, 1972.

Ibid. Il me semble que l'interét de mon travail jusqu'aujourd'hui a été la recherche d'unton. C'est un problème de forme et qui explique peut-être mon appartenance à ce qu'on a appelé le nouveau roman. Mais il serait erroné de me croire partisan d'une école du regard. S'il s'agit d'être objectif, l'oreille a d'aussi tyranniques exigences. Or le ton varie d'un de mes livres à l'autre. C'est que la recherche en ce domaine ne sera jamais finie. Choisir à chaque fois, par goût du neuf, un ton entre les milliards qu'a enrigistrés l'oreille, voilà mon lot.

Levine and Madden (New York: Oxford University Press, 1968), esp. pp. 352–54. The EYEBALL input must be transcribed in a machine-readable form, but the text can be entered either from cards or card-image files. Since input is treated as a stream of characters, record boundaries are not observed, although split words should not be hyphenated. All punctuation marks may be retained. Most computer-usable material which has different format can, of course, be edited by simple programs to conform to these requirements.
